Bruce, you may want to also add that when they wait for those fr=
agments they are in fact Mike and Lisa's voice not just any male or female =
voice.  They are ones that you identify as being theirs.
 
Julimllejade <le=
ongbabe@...> wrote:


Thanks for the fast reply, Bruce! Definitely some=
thing to add to my notes for further examination.Sharon--- In EVP-ITC@yahoo=
groups.com, bruce halliday <paranormalinvestigating@...> wrote:>> > Sharon,=
> > In my experience through research, most of the time mike will wait for =
a masculine fragment or signal> and lisa will wait for a feminine one. I be=
lieve they try to answer in the apropriate gender so that I > don't get con=
fused about who is answering. Sometimes I will get a response or message th=
at is made > up of both male and female voices together, even in the same w=
ord sometimes but very rarely.> > And I think when that occurs it's because=
 they lose the particular fragment midstream and pick up > whatever is avai=
lable at that instant to complete the message , word or phrase.> > I hope t=
his answers your question and please keep asking them. It forces me to form=
ulate an answer> and you to further your knowledge as a researcher. That's =
what it's all about.> > Bruce> Bruce Halliday > > > To: EVP-ITC@...: leongb=
abe@...: Fri, 11 Jan 2008 16:26:18 +0000Subject: [EVP-ITC] Male and female =
voices joined to create one response?> > > > > Bruce,Is it common to receiv=
e a response comprised of a mixture of men and women sound bytes/voices (li=
ke I heard in this one)? My guess is that we hear predominantly male voices=
 because they're more male radio announcers. Therefore, does the entity who=
 announces herself to you as Lisa come through with a male voice at times (=
because those are the voices that she gets most of the time to formulate a =
response)? Please tell me if my reasoning here is way off base...Thanks,Sha=
